data.text:
Luckily I was able to read the NYTimes article since my family has a subscription. As usual, well written BR!

RIP Mohammed Yusuf Khan aka Dilip Kumar, a towering institution of acting as Madan rightly pointed out. Like MANK said, Ashok Kumar, Motilal and Balraj Sahni may have been the first to popularize natural acting in Hindi cinema, but Dilip took it to another level entirely and remained probably the first actor-star who was at the top for a long time. He made method acting his own and was also a great song actor. Whatever films I watched him, whether it was Mehboob Khan‚Äôs Andaz with Nargis and Raj Kapoor (yes my fellow millennials, I am one of the very few who watches older films), Madhumati, Aan or his latter films like Shakti, Mashaal and Saudagar, his magnetic presence and acting was the first thing would grab my attention and I would be hooked. I echo MANK and Madan that his greatest legacy is that he inspired multiple generations of actors like Amitabh, Kamal, SRK and perhaps Manoj Bajpai. Yet, he still to this day towers over all of them.

Everyone will have their top 5 or top 10 lists of great Indian actors and Dilip will definitely be part of those lists. Even though Kamini Kaushal (his first love) is still around, he was the main link to the ‚ÄúGolden Era‚Äù and now he‚Äôs departed. Of course, many of his fans would have wished for him to hit 100, but 98 is a solid innings.

My dear condolences to Saira Banu for being his constant companion for 5 decades and his caretaker during his last years.

If you want to honor his legacy, most of his movies are on YouTube and please do take advantage to watch them.

Also RIP Richard Donner. Thank you for Superman, Lethal Weapon, the Goonies, Scrooged and The Donner Cut of Superman II (I have not and will not watch the Lester version). And most importantly thank you for giving us Christopher Reeve, RIP.

RIP Dilip Kumar.

Dilip Kumar and Amitabh Bachan have made me cry tonnes of tears in the movie Shakthi. It was one of the first movies that I ever watched. My dad had it in his movie collection and I remember watching it quite often in my childhood.

Dilip Kumar saying ‚Äúmein bhi tumse mohabbat kartha hoon, bete‚Äù and hugging Amitabh in the movie‚Äôs climax is how I remember him.

Sad to see all these great actors who have entertained and made my life colorful through their movies pass away one by one.

He was way more talented in comparison to his contemporaries. From whatever little I saw of his work, he didn‚Äôt resort to making faces in the name of acting. His performances were always very internalized and pitch-perfect. When he cried, I cried with him.

It might sound silly‚Ä¶.. but actors passing away hurts, bcoz I always feel like they are a part of one‚Äôs life/childhood. Actors and movies evoke emotionally charged memories.

Dilip Kumar and Shakthi takes me back to the comfort of my childhood home, the safety & comfort of my parents‚Äô presence, and carefree days.

‚ÄúHe wrote ‚ÄúHistory of Indian cinema‚Äù, he did not write ‚ÄúIndian movie industry‚Äù. History will of course include movie personalities from all over India, and so it will include Dilip Kumar.‚Äù ‚Äì The problem isn‚Äôt just with the words history of Indian cinema but what he said further ‚Äì that it will always be before Dilip Kumar and after Dilip Kumar. I think it‚Äôs an extreme stretch to assume the impact of DK was uniformly as strong on all regional cinema as on Hindi cinema to make that statement valid. Yes, he influenced actors from all over to some degree but would it necessarily be a before/after effect in say Tamil or Bengali cinema? Don‚Äôt think so. AB‚Äôs statement is perfectly valid for Hindi cinema ‚Äì as BR said ‚Äì but an exaggeration when it comes to INDIAN cinema. The larger issue is those immersed in ONLY Hindi cinema culture make the unconscious assumption that Hindi and Indian cinema are equivalent. I don‚Äôt think most down South would agree. Or, for that matter, South Indian language speakers living ‚Äòup North‚Äô (to the extent you could call Mumbai north which nobody other than South Indians would do) like me.

This is sort of what Rahul has also addressed:

‚Äù a case may be made for Dilip Kumar being a national icon if either he was well known in the south (like Amitabh) or if a sizable number of well known actors had acknowledged a debt to him while he was alive ( like many in the Hindi film industry have). I think that none of the two is true, but I could be wrong.‚Äù ‚Äì Exactly. Kamal acknowledged DK in the obits but Kamal is ulaganayagan, he is very well informed about cinema in Hindi as well as abroad. I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if some young South actors actually heard about DK only now that he is dead. Your example is perfect. DK was a colossus beyond doubt but for all India influence, he was no match for AB.

@kaveri hats off to you for being brave and mentioning the fact ‚Ä¶

There is HARDLY any doubt that the NYT panders to a certain section of readers who are quite happy with‚Ä¶ you know what‚Ä¶

While I take great offense to the the term ‚ÄòHindu Nationalists‚Äô, I didn‚Äôt expect BR Saab to fall into that trap because he is someone who UNDERSTANDS the nuances of making such statements. If BR Saab is trying to say that even GREAT artists like Dilip Kumar aren‚Äôt spared the dirt of politics, I would agree; in the same vein as when Chaplin was pulled up during McCarthysim. While this is a left-leaning blog, BR Saab has been kind enough to let folks like us write and comment upon what we feel differently. It is not his ‚Äòleft-leaning‚Äô tendency, but it it his humanity that is letting folks like us comment. [That is what I think; if BR Saab thinks differently and that he believes in left-leaning ideology, that is his personal choice.]

And here‚Äôs my take; there‚Äôs NO GLORY left writing for the NYT: Least of all, BR Saab has written better pieces here than on that newspaper. To be honest with you BR Saab, a very disappointing piece pandering to the needs of newspapers like NYT and WP whose star-writers are Aatish Taseer and Rana Ayuub.

This is the SAME NYT that put out the racist cartoon ‚Ä¶ here I am referring to another left-leaning ‚Äòprint‚Äô‚Ä¶

https://www.firstpost.com/world/nyts-mangalyaan-cartoon-yes-its-racism-no-its-not-about-modis-us-visit-1739185.html

And finally, that you for hearing folks like us out ‚Ä¶

AnJo: Firstpost was right leaning in those days as I believe R Jagannathan was still in charge then. But that hardly matters as the NYT cartoon is self explanatory. To be frank, I don‚Äôt mind it as it‚Äôs a cartoon and a cartoon should be allowed to give offence. But NYT has been at the forefront of not applying those standards anymore and devoting copious column inches to arguing why cartoons, in fact ANY words, can be more lethal than an AK47 round. If that is so, why the f is that cartoon still up there? And yes it is, I opened the NYT link. I knew before I learnt of this cartoon that their much vaunted wokeness is entirely performative and devoid of substance and this only confirms my view. The only reason they even pretend to be woke is US millennials and zoomers are very vocal against racism and this outlet like others will sink if they depend on the subscription of boomers alone.

Still a sinking ship. Had a subscription until I found out how hollow their columnist Bari Weiss was. Yuck. And even before then, I had noticed that their op-ed was literally just that ‚Äì reams of polemic and not much commentary. They do have or used to have three conservative columnists for balance but balance wasn‚Äôt the problem, the content was.

All right then, didn‚Äôt quite expect to see such depth of hate for the NYT in this space ‚Ä¶.. not that there aren‚Äôt plenty of things to criticize about the paper. I‚Äôve been dismayed by the strangling of all ‚Äúnon-woke‚Äù voices in its opinion pages. Whether one agrees with Bari Weiss or not or for that matter with Sen.Tom Cotton, for that point of view to be silenced rather than rebutted and for the opinion page editor to be pushed out in the latter case is troubling. That said the news features, investigative reporting, long form deep dives, pandemic reporting are of a high quality and it is still the US‚Äôs preeminent newspaper. I admit I don‚Äôt get my India news from the NYT simply because it‚Äôs not a focus and is a minuscule part of its coverage. For every perceived ‚Äúhit job‚Äù on India, I think there are also positive pieces though it‚Äôs the negative stuff that sticks in memory. I can recall at least a few positive opinion pieces on India by Tom Friedman in the past. At any rate, this is not a sponsored post üòâ and my goal is not to change any minds but merely to present an alternative view even if mine is the only one!

Apologies brangan for digressing from what is a tribute to Dilip Kumar rather than a critique of the NYT. I was taken aback by the vitriolic dismissal of the entirety of the NYT‚Äôs work as a yellow rag and trash. I‚Äôm mostly a silent reader and don‚Äôt comment a whole lot so this kind of derailment isn‚Äôt likely to be a regular thing üòâ Also, I hope you get to contribute to the NYT again, I‚Äôll be cheering! üòÄ

‚Äúnot that there aren‚Äôt plenty of things to criticize about the paper. ‚Äù ‚Äì In that case, why do you feel the need to classify negative comments about it as ‚Äòvitriol‚Äô? If a newspaper is unjustifiably hyped living on its past glory even as its current content goes down the drain, the reaction to that is bound to be strong.

My concern is not with how they cover India. I agree with you that it is a miniscule part of their reporting and that goes for most newspapers and outlets abroad, something that Indians with delusional ideas about our international influence cannot seem to digest. Actually a tribute to DK on the NYT pages is a minor miracle in that regard.

What I cannot condone is their neocon turn in the 21st century much like CNN which too had previously had enjoyed a stellar reputation in the TV news world. It is very hard to believe anymore that this paper too, like WaPo, had published the Pentagon Papers back in the 70s. That truly ‚Äòliberal‚Äô side of the paper like other mainstream outlets is dead (underscored by their perfunctory obituaries for Mike Gravel himself) while a make believe wokeness is plastered over its content to conceal the fact that they are now essentially in the business of manufacturing consent for the establishment.

It is not a completely unexpected outcome as newspaper readership has caved in across the world. You see that in TV news too that everyone is either a former Democrat or Republican operative or, well, a CIA intern whether officially disclosed or not. But in that case, it becomes difficult to axiomatically accept the content of a newspaper or TV channel as great or reliable merely because of its past reputation (after all, how do I know when Joe Scarborough isn‚Äôt trying to insert a Republican talking point and when he is). The one outlet I might still give that benefit of doubt to some extent is BBC but it too is increasingly embattled. In other words, it‚Äôs not a singling out of NYT ‚Äì WaPo, WSJ are all pale shadows of their former selves. I have an Atlantic subscription‚Ä¶for now. Not without their flaws either but they publish the kind of political pieces that I never got from NYT during the 2-3 years I had the subscription (which is a long enough time especially in the Trump era). Like this one‚Ä¶

https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2021/07/george-packer-four-americas/619012/

@Madan: There are negative comments and then there‚Äôs outright trashing of everything the paper stands for. To me it seems like the collective criticism reflects the latter and perhaps to you it‚Äôs not shrug

I agree that the paper is not the liberal bastion of the past but as you acknowledged the environment politically, socially and economically has changed and with it the paper has too. Aspects of the coverage (for me in particular the opinion pages) are troubling but I find plenty of solid, hard reporting, tracking and information. I like the Atlantic too ‚Äì Ed Yong had in my book the best coverage of the pandemic. I‚Äôve always loved reading George Packer from his days with the New Yorker. But then there are journalists I like reading in the New Yorker too. I often pick and choose based on the journalists whose work I like much as I read/watch brangan and perhaps not others on FC. In general I find dismissing all of something out of hand somewhat problematic ‚Äì but that‚Äôs me, others clearly disagree and that‚Äôs fine.

@krishikari ‚Äì laughed out loud at your second comment! Thanks. üôÇ

BR ‚Äì I agree with you ‚Äì even today, writing for the NYT is a huge thing for any journalist. And the grand old lady still has decent investigative reporters and decent coverage.

That said, I found your piece sadly lacking in your usual brilliant prose. I don‚Äôt know what went wrong, or even if you think it did at all, but it was the most pedantic piece of writing I‚Äôve ever seen from you. Honestly, if I hadn‚Äôt gone back and looked at the by-line, I would have thought that ‚ÄòMujib Mashal‚Äô (whoever he is, god bless him!) was the writer. DK deserved more, surely?

Your success on FC is well-earned. You don‚Äôt need to prove your writing credentials to anyone. And video reviews are definitely taking the place of print/written reviews. All that is true.

But do allow me to mourn ‚Äì a little ‚Äì the demise of a great writer, someone whose reviews, quips, analyses, critiques, have given me hours and hours of reading pleasure. I miss it. I wager I‚Äôm not the only one.

C‚Äôest la vie! Onwards‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThat said, I found your piece sadly lacking in your usual brilliant prose. I don‚Äôt know what went wrong, or even if you think it did at all, but it was the most pedantic piece of writing I‚Äôve ever seen from you. Honestly, if I hadn‚Äôt gone back and looked at the by-line, I would have thought that ‚ÄòMujib Mashal‚Äô (whoever he is, god bless him!) was the writer. DK deserved more, surely?‚Äù Absolutely, I am feeling bad to echo this. It reminded me of once BR writing for Malayalam Manorama. The piece had the makings to enter the generic world of Malayalam Manorama. But, we don‚Äôt read BR for that. Do we? All through the piece, I kept searching for the old BR who would show us through his brilliant prose how the tugs of his heartstrings were stirred by a particular moment from a movie that you can only expect BR to remember. I remember Manoram‚Äôs terrific ‚ÄúMistress of Arts‚Äù obituary now as I write this, and man, that is the gold BR standard. BR has promised something big for his August piece. Eagerly awaiting for it:)

Every big Western publication has a house style, and I had to conform to it (which was not an issue to me at all).

This is how my original draft began.

Dilip Kumar, who passed away at the age of xx, was the last survivor of the triumvirate of actors that ruled Hindi cinema in the 1950s-60s, each of them fashioning a distinct screen persona. Raj Kapoor‚Äòs signature role was that of the Chaplinesque na√Øf constantly negotiating a world that‚Äôs lost its innocence. Dev Anand, known as the Gregory Peck of India, became a stylish matinee idol. Dilip Kumar‚Äôs reputation as a Method Actor would suggest an affinity with Marlon Brando, but in his autobiography titled The Substance and the Shadow, Kumar said, ‚ÄúThe epithet was used for me much before it was used for Brando. The truth is that I am an actor who evolved a method‚Ä¶ I learned the importance of studying the script and characters deeply and building upon my own gut observations and sensations about my own and other characters.‚Äù

Kumar wasn‚Äôt the first actor to break free from the semaphoric, silent movie-style acting popularised by stars like Sohrab Modi and Prithviraj Kapoor. There were actors like Motilal and Ashok Kumar. The latter, a huge star much before Kumar entered films, was the one who planted the seed in Kumar‚Äôs mind: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very simple. You just do what you would do in the situation if you were really in it. If you act it will be acting and it will look very silly.‚Äù Kumar took this advice so seriously that his preparation for scenes became the stuff of legend.

But the criticism that Dilip Kumar declined after Ganga Jamuna is valid. One reason for this was that after GJ- which he had officially written and produced (and unofficially directed) was a big critical and commercial success- he started becoming the ghost writer and ghost director on all his films. He was just not cut out for this , but he was too egotistical to realize this. Hence the string of disasters like Leader, Aadmi, Dil diya dard liya etc, where DK‚Äôs performances became more and more labored and self-indulgent. Reportedly on Bairaag, in which he played a triple role, DK shot close to 100 hrs. or so of footage, with his constant retakes and improvisations driving up the budget and schedule to herculean proportions. The film turned out to be one of his worst, and he went into exile for 5 years after this disaster. On his return, he did stick only to acting, and when he did attempt an official directorial debut with ‚ÄúKalinga‚Äù, the results were so bad that the producer refused to release the film. Subhash Ghai, who saw the film at a trial show at the thespian‚Äôs request, was so embarrassed by what he saw that he escaped during the intermission without speaking to DK -whom he admired a lot. No wonder that DK did not speak about this film in his autobiography, the whole exercise turned out to be a nightmare for him, with the producer threatening to burn the film‚Äôs negatives.

And I don‚Äôt think DK did any sort of reinvention as an actor, he only stagnated and became outdated. His performances in films like Footpath, Madhumati and Mughal -e ‚Äì Azam looks more modern than the ones in Kranti or Qila. Also, what Naseer says about DK limiting his film appearances and driving up demand may not be intentional on DK‚Äôs part, but it was affective in maintaining at least a perception of his stardom and importance across decades. He remained a bigger star for the industry rather than for the audiences. This is very Unlike Bachchan, who is very much a great modern (and traditional) actor who could seamlessly move from masala film lead roles to character parts and still remain prolific.

I agree to some extent with Naseer‚Äôs critique.

The parts I don‚Äôt agree with are:

a) That DK ushered in the dreaded star system ‚Äì No, the South already had it and/or would have had it with or without him. And Shammi was on his way to becoming a star anyway in the 60s even as DK entered his indulgent phase.

b) That DK should have mentored and nurtured actors ‚Äì Very few do it worldwide. I would like to know how many actors has Naseer mentored.

c) Speaking of which, Nas himself has fared much worse than DK in the movies he did for money, like Krishh or Dirty Picture. I know he will find a way to blame that too on DK and AB leaving so space for pure character actors like him but he could have found other ways to satisfy himself and also make a better living, like emulating Saeed Jaffrey.

Now the part I agree with is that in essence, DK became a brand to be repeated over and over and his later innings soured memories of his talent (where AB, notwithstanding the odd misstep, largely furthered his legacy in his second innings). I agree with what MANK said that DK was the actor that the industry romanced over but AB was the all round master (of course AnJo is hardly going to disagree with this anyway üôÇ ).

I sort of see it this way. Hollywood evolved from the straight delivery-smoothness of Grant/Peck/Burton/Harrison to the introduction of stylized method acting via Marlon Brando to which Pacino and DeNiro added much needed grit and muscle. I obviously don‚Äôt mean muscle in a macho way as neither Pacino nor DeNiro were renowned for their physique. But they conveyed a rawer, rougher aesthetic and reveled in it. They moved acting from the uber nuance of Brando to high octane intensity that the masses too could connect with. You can only move on to appreciating the great Brits like Alec Guinness, Gary Oldman or DDL AFTER Pacino and DeNiro have shown you the potential of acting in more commercial films. This is what AB achieved too with DK being the Brando parallel and the previous Prithviraj/Ashok Kumar generation being the parallel of Grant/Peck.

BR Saab please delete the above comment and paste this ‚Äì I believe the links are working here ‚Ä¶

There‚Äôs a history behind Naseer‚Äôs jealousy, anger, and frustration in that order. He realized too soon, and wisely so, that he just wasn‚Äôt cut out for the ‚Äònavarasa‚Äô type of acting so easily achievable for Amit and then Dilip, again, in that order. To his credit, he learnt it, but he never forgot it. In his memoir, ‚ÄòAnd then One Day‚Äô, he acknowledges that ONLY Amit and Dilip could fulfill the requirements of Hindi cinema in totality. [Goddamn, the man uses 2.5 pages of his autobiography to diss ‚ÄòSHOLAY.‚Äô This is the equivalent of a hatred timeline as maintained by Rakhee as in ‚ÄòMERE KARAN ARJUN AAYENGE!‚Äô] His main grouse is against directors like Benegal, Nihalani who went ahead with main-stream stars after the art-house films fizzled out in the late ‚Äô80s. He was always of the opinion that where would Benegal and Nihalani find actors who would herald pigs across a river in PAAR or play a disturbed MOHAN JOSHI in ‚ÄòMohan Joshi Haazir Ho!

In the meantime, Smita went on to ‚ÄòNAMAK HALAL‚Äô and ‚ÄòSHAKTI‚Äô. Basically,, it is his complete failure in understanding that an artiste can survive wherever if he is talented enough. And Goddam, Naseer is talented as one can get. If a Kamal Haasan can take the bold step of venturing into commercial ventures inspite of his short stature and bad voice ‚Äî [I recently watched a clip of the DOSTANA Tamil remake; I forget the name; the scene where Zeenat lodges a complaint regarding eve-teasing and Bachchan, oh so cool that he is ‚Äî chewing a gum and chides Zeenat ‚Äî Hassan looks so bad, so weak in the Tamil movie compared to Amit; and Amit keeps oozing out style and charisma thanks to his height and voice and his mastery over this form of commercial acting.] Naseer simply forgets and fails to acknowledge this form of acting! By that logic, almost ALL Marathi films, including Lagoo‚Äôs and Patekar‚Äôs NATASAMRAT, need to be considered the embodiment of bad acting!!

Amit was the first choice for ARDH SATYA. But by that time, Amit had exhausted all the cop roles and with the breaK-through ‚ÄòZANJEER‚Äô, there was hardly anything he could add to Dilip Chitre‚Äôs all-encompassing poem on ‚ÄòArdh Satya‚Äô and Pancake‚Äôs story ‚ÄòSURYA.‚Äô And then he had ‚ÄòINQUILAAB‚Äô coming next! So it turned out to be a gift that Amit didn‚Äôt act in that one with Om and the brilliant performance of Amrapurkar as ‚ÄòRama Shetty‚Äô locking horns!

The one thing that pricks Naseer to this date is why the ‚Äòchampions‚Äô of parallel cinema movement moved on to commercial starts like Karishma, Bajpayee, and of course, Nihalani with ‚ÄòDev.‚Äô [Nihalani had a life-long desire to with Amit; and he even surrogately worked with the family when he cast Jaya in ‚ÄòHAZAAR CHAURASI KI MAA.‚Äô

Naseer got really pissed off when Nihalani chose Amit for ‚ÄòDEV.‚Äô It was a life-long desire of Nihalani to work with Amit and it bore fruition in ‚ÄòDEV.‚Äô So Naseer went on a tirade to down-play Amit‚Äôs acting skills and over-praising Om‚Äôs skills: The tragedy is, being such a wonderful actor ‚Äì who was called out by the great NYT as the ‚Äòblind‚Äô actor ‚Äì he forgot that in the context of the movie, Om is a hard-liner and he acts with a tenor and pitch in line with his thinking: ‚ÄòSab Choohe hai Saale‚Äô Bil Mein Ghuske Maarna Chahiye‚Äô to Amit‚Äôs soft-spoken, low-pitch voice: ‚ÄòKya Kar Rahe Ho tum? Tum in bhatke hue naujawaano ko aur, aur door bhagaa rahe ho‚Ä¶!

I prefer stars over franchises any day, so god bless the star system.

Ditto üôÇ . I think i have seen the Hindi version of Sagina, and i don‚Äôt remember all that much about it. i have not seen the Bengali version which DK is so proud of.

Goddamn, the man uses 2.5 pages of his autobiography to diss ‚ÄòSHOLAY.‚Äô This is the equivalent of a hatred timeline as maintained by Rakhee as in ‚ÄòMERE KARAN ARJUN AAYENGE!‚Äô

An Jo that was lol üôÇ . Naseer was also angry with Ketan Mehta when he cast Amitabh as Mangal Pandey in Kartoos, of course that film didn‚Äôt get made at the time and it was later made with Aamir. Naseer and Aamir fought bitterly while shooting for Sarfarosh, as Aamir felt that Naseer wasn‚Äôt taking his work seriously, but that was just Naseer‚Äôs usual attitude towards mainstream films. But Naseer had great respect for Aamir as the only producer in Bollywood who gave importance to the quality of his films rather than making money. Naseer had also disowned all his parallel films including Paar, when he saw art film directors working in the mainstream with big stars.

Btw the remake of Dostana was called ‚ÄúSattam‚Äù in Tamil

Naseer and Aamir fought bitterly while shooting for Sarfarosh,

I don‚Äôt know about them fighting ‚Äòbitterly‚Äô because neither man is prone to behaving that way, but yes, they didn‚Äôt shoot together. Not even for one scene. Every scene of theirs was shot separately and spliced together at editing stage.

@Madan, I thought Sarfarosh was the one film which didn‚Äôt fall into the jingoism trap. Sure, they named Pakistan outright for fomenting terror in India ‚Äì which films didn‚Äôt until then, preferring to euphemistically call it ‚Äòhamaare padosi mulk ‚Äì but there was an acknowledgement that Indians who helped them out of greed (or whatever) were equally culpable. I also liked the attention paid to how Muslims are treated ‚Äì Mukesh Rishi‚Äôs character was extremely nuanced, not the token Muslim at all. It was interesting to see the subject treated seriously but without the usual ‚ÄòBlame Pakistan for all our ills‚Äô and chest-thumping that you usually see in films.

Nasir has been extremely honest in his autobiography ‚Äì he had said that a lot of his ire towards AB is because he wanted to be him, but couldn‚Äôt master the beats of mainstream cinema. He‚Äôs ‚Äì to use a phrase popular on social media ‚Äì ‚Äòcomplicated‚Äô.

Anu Warrier: Well, Sarfarosh was definitely a lot better than the median Bollywood level of jingoism which is why I said it was in there here and there. I didn‚Äôt like bits like the mulk scene where the Aamir character says in a very tone deaf way that the mulk needs more like Mukesh Rishi at which point Mukesh schools him. And the crux of the plot itself was an uncomfortable insinuation that Mehdi Hassan curried favour for Pakistan because there are too many similarities between him and Ghulfam Hassan (the name itself is a clumsy composite of Ghulam Ali and Mehdi Hassan). Nothing ever came up, not even in the form of rumours, to suggests Mehdi did so and he had his admirers in India for many years after the film, still does. So I didn‚Äôt get what that angle of a ghazal singer being a spy in disguise was all about. Maybe had the makers not left such blatant references to real Pak ghazal singers, I would have accepted that premise as simply fiction. But the way it was done, they made it look like they had some hot take that they had had to disguise to avoid defamation when it was more likely based on just a run-of-the-mill conspiracy theory.

@Madan: where the Aamir character says in a very tone deaf way that the mulk needs more like Mukesh Rishi at which point Mukesh schools him.

But I think the point was to emphasise what Mukesh tells him ‚Äì most people are like Aamir in the movie, tarring every single Muslim with the same brush. That scene was set up so Mukesh could make a very pertinent point.

I didn‚Äôt know ‚Äì and have never read ‚Äì about Ghulam Hassan being a stand-in for Mehdi Hassan. Ever. And the fact that Mehdi Hassan continued to be beloved on both sides of the border is testimony that no one made that connection either. So where/when did this conspiracy theory come from, I wonder.

The only singer I know who was accused of spying for the Pakistani government was Adnan Sami in recent times, though strangely enough Dilip Kumar was accused of working for the Pakistanis, poor guy!

@MANK ‚Äì Nasir said so in an interview. In fact, he stated that he didn‚Äôt know what the problem was that Aamir had (‚ÄúYou should ask him.‚Äù) but they didn‚Äôt shot a single scene together.

I don‚Äôt usually pay attention to the stars‚Äô personal lives but whatever the reason for the divorce, I wouldn‚Äôt say ‚ÄòPoor Kiran‚Äô.
